return_description: A new NSDecimalNumber object whose value is the sum of the receiver and decimalNumber.

Methods.method_description: Adds this number to another given number.

return_description: A new NSDecimalNumber object whose value is decimalNumber subtracted from the receiver.

Methods.method_description: Subtracts another given number from this one.

return_description: A new NSDecimalNumber object whose value is decimalNumber multiplied by the receiver.

Methods.method_description: Multiplies the number by another given number.

return_description: A new NSDecimalNumber object whose value is the value of the receiver divided by decimalNumber.

Methods.method_description: Divides the number by another given number.

return_description: A new NSDecimalNumber object whose value is the value of the receiver raised to the power power.

Methods.method_description: Raises the number to a given power.
Multiplies the number by 10 raised to the given power.

return_description: NSOrderedAscending if the value of decimalNumber is greater than the receiver; NSOrderedSame if they’re equal; and NSOrderedDescending if the value of decimalNumber is less than the receiver.

Methods.method_description: Compares this decimal number and another.

A decimal number that specifies no number.
The way arithmetic methods round off and handle error conditions.

The exception raised on divide by zero.

class_description:
NSDecimalNumber, an immutable subclass of NSNumber, provides an object-oriented wrapper for doing base-10 arithmetic. An instance can represent any number that can be expressed as mantissa x 10^exponent where mantissa is a decimal integer up to 38 digits long, and exponent is an integer from –128 through 127.
Important
The Swift overlay to the Foundation framework provides the Decimal structure, which bridges to the NSDecimalNumber class. For more information about value types, see Working with Cocoa Frameworks in Using Swift with Cocoa and Objective-C (Swift 4.1).
